page.title: 14Flora at Durlston
page.content: Much of the flora of our study area is typical of chalkland scenery. There are over 400 different species of wild flowers - speedwell, scarlet pimpernel, yellow rattle, ox eye daisy, charlock, dog rose and cranesbill being amongst the most common. Apart from these there are many different types of orchid, some quite rare such as the pyramidal, bee, and early spider orchid. Thrift is abundant on the salty cliffs, and in the early spring cowslips abound in the fields. Hedgerows of hawthorn, bramble and blackthorn surround fields and cover old quarry spoil heaps.Ivy clings to many of the stone walls and here and there clumps of nettles and docks cover areas of thin soil.Trees in the area include oak, ash, beech, sycamore and Scot's pine.
